I quite like zoos. People come to zoos because they want to see animals such as lions, giraffes, rhinos, elephants, tigers, penguins, crocodiles, and many more, but zoos are like animal prisons. The animals are kept in an enclosure where there is very little room to explore. They can just get fed up and bored with being in the same place all the time. It does, however, keep them safe from poachers, and animals from an endangered species may need to be kept in zoos for the sake of the species' survival. The big question is, are they better off being vulnerable to poaching, or being cooped up in a zoo?

Reply: Thanks for listening to this podcast!

I really have some vivid memories from visiting the zoo in the city where my grandma lives. I used to be extremely excited to see some massive animals that (to be honest) I had seen in different science books. It was such a huge opportunity for my little brother and me to detach from the chaotic urban area as well. Unfortunately, I have to say that this zoo has become much emptier these days, and the only things left are some bears and (probably) some aquariums filled with little fish. However, this place didn't used to be a huge one where there had been so many species like lions or even elephants, but maybe one where people usually hung out, considering that there is a gigantic park right before you enter the zoo. I haven't visited this zoo since 2019, but I still have a deep feeling that this place is not popular anymore, as most animals died from natural causes. Over time, my perspective on animals kept in zoos has changed dramatically. When I was a child, visiting a place like this was the only opportunity to see them in real life, but now I feel deeply disappointed by the way they are treated.
